<<<<<<< HEAD
The tranquillitie of the minde A verye excellent and most comfortable oration, plainely directing euerye man, & woman, to the true tranquillitie and quyetnesse of their minde. Compyled in Latine by Iohn Barnarde, student in the Vniuersity of Cambridge, now lately translated into Englishe by Anthony Marten. Oratio pia, religiosa, et solatii plena, de vera animi tranquillitate. English Bernard, John, d. 1567? Marten, Anthony, d. 1597.
[8], 108 leaves
By Henry Denham, for Wylliam Norton, Anno. 1570. Imprinted at London : [1570]
Translation of: Oratio pia, religiosa, et solatii plena, de vera animi tranquillitate. Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.
=======
The tranquillitie of the minde A verye excellent and most comfortable oration, plainely directing euerye man, & woman, to the true tranquillitie and quyetnesse of their minde. Compyled in Latine by Iohn Barnarde, student in the Vniuersity of Cambridge, now lately translated into Englishe by Anthony Marten. Oratio pia, religiosa, et solatii plena, de vera animi tranquillitate. English Bernard, John, d. 1567? Marten, Anthony, d. 1597.
[8], 108 leaves
By Henry Denham, for Wylliam Norton, Anno. 1570. Imprinted at London : [1570]
Translation of: Oratio pia, religiosa, et solatii plena, de vera animi tranquillitate. Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.
